forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
Are you talking about "Full XP" ***or*** about a "PE"? :smile: (they are two different things).  

I can see a lot of nice screenshots :tongue:, but actually no info about what you have done and what you want to do. :tongue:  

Maybe it's better if you wait for **Lancelot** (he is Turkish) to reply you on the other "regional" thread:  
[http://www.boot-land...?...ic=8614\&hl=](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=8614&hl= "External link")  

Anyway, Welcome to the board. :tongue:  

![:idea:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/idea.gif)  

jaclaz

forumNotes.author: knoppix
forumNotes.content:
> Are you talking about "Full XP" ***or*** about a "PE"? ![:idea:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/idea.gif) (they are two different things).
i convert "PE" to "Full xp" i can add/remove programs and a lot of full xp functions. but only can't use network.

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
> i convert "PE" to "Full xp" > i can add/remove programs and a lot of full xp functions. NO. :smile: You do not "convert" anything into "anything else", unless you are a magician :tongue:, and if you were one, you won't be here asking for help ![:idea:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/idea.gif). Answer this simple quesion: Which loader do you use to start your "whatever" :tongue:: * SETUPLDR.BIN * NTLDR
If right answer is 1., it's a PE, if it's 2. it's a XP. jaclaz P.S.: just in case, SETUPLDR.BIN renamed to NTLDR counts as SETUPLDR.BIN :tongue:

forumNotes.author: knoppix
forumNotes.content:
it is not importont boot loader. u use maybe grub4dos but i make some change on winpe and so i can use a lot of xp function on it and i can boot it anywhere _____________________ 1-i install a clear xp on my laptop with no drivers and no any more programs. 2-install winpe to usb flash disk (4gb) 3-on the full clear xp , i run "regedit" and export registry and save it; eg:addreg.reg 4-then edit this reg file and change all path (c:\\program files) to (x:\\programs) and (c:\\windows) to (x:\\i386) and all (c:\\\*\*) to (x:\\\*\*) and copy this file to usb (i386\\system32) 5- then edit "software" file where (i386\\system32\\config) and add value to the (microsoft\\windows\\currentversion\\run) that "hiderun /w reg import addreg.reg) 6- then copy all files into the windows folder in the usb i386 folder (not only system32\\config folder) then boot from usb so alot of function is running.

but the tcp/ip service is not running and if i add or remove any program , then i run regedit and export the registry x:\\i386\\system32\\addreg.reg) so the registry updating.

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
> it is not importont boot loader.

No, the boot loader isn't important, but the **OS** loader is. ![:idea:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/idea.gif)  

What you have appears like a PE, ***NOT*** a "full XP".  

FYI, you can have a "real" "full XP" on USB stick.  

jaclaz

normally u can't.

forumNotes.content:
> if you have a better idea please share it.

NOT necessarily "better" :smile:, simply if you want a "full XP" on USB, build one. (just do it :tongue:)  

Only trying NOT to confuse apples with oranges. ![:idea:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/idea.gif)

:tongue:

> what is your "full xp" I already gave you all the links in the world (and even more) :tongue:. Add to them UNIATA and UNIVBE: [http://www.boot-land...hp?showforum=60](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showforum=60 "External link") and the Drivers Pack: [http://driverpacks.net/](http://driverpacks.net/ "External link")

forumNotes.author: online
forumNotes.content:
> "all" is a very "heavy" word. Yep, I couldn't agree more! :tongue: > My "full XP" can boot a vast number of PC's My one too! :smile: :tongue: By the way, never known you had your own "Full XP"... :tongue:
@knoppix > i want to use full xp on usb flash disk. Please, note that (at least in a good communication) the naming is (very) important. Your PE environment, even if it does some things that other PEs do not (yet) do, is NOT a "Full XP": it remains a PE environment, with its advantages and its limits. So, if you want to really use a "Full XP" from your UFD then you can follow the suggestions that **jaclaz** has already pointed (or even you can perform a tutorial in my signature). Indeed, if you want "only" to enhance the *featuring* of your current PE environment, then please detail much more your network-issue: I'm sure that any member "PE-oriented" could help you. ![:idea:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/idea.gif)

forumNotes.author: MedEvil
forumNotes.content:
The used OS loader does **not** make the difference between a 'Full XP' and a PE. The registry setting SystemSetupInProgress does! It is quite possible to load a 'Full XP' with setupldr or a PE with ntldr. Though the adapting is usually a real pain in the behind! :tongue: What knoppix does: - augmenting a PE with all XP files --\> still a PE - towards the end of the boot cycle he overwrites the complete PE registry with a 'Full XP' one. --\> To all files startet after this point, the OS is a 'Full XP'. To all files started before this point it is still a PE. So the end result is a hybrid system, with one part reacting exactly like a PE, while the other reacts exactly like a 'Full XP'. I would guess that the behavior of the system as a whole is mostly unpredictable, due to its hybrid nature. But due to it's PE nature during the early booting stages, it will without doubt have the same ability to run on 'all' hardware that every PE has.
![:idea:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/idea.gif)

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
> The used OS loader does **not** make the difference between a 'Full XP' and a PE. The registry setting SystemSetupInProgress does! > It is quite possible to load a 'Full XP' with setupldr or a PE with ntldr. Though the adapting is usually a real pain in the behind! :tongue: > > What knoppix does: > - augmenting a PE with all XP files --\> still a PE > - towards the end of the boot cycle he overwrites the complete PE registry with a 'Full XP' one. --\> To all files startet after this point, the OS is a 'Full XP'. To all files started before this point it is still a PE. > > So the end result is a hybrid system, with one part reacting exactly like a PE, while the other reacts exactly like a 'Full XP'. > > I would guess that the behavior of the system as a whole is mostly unpredictable, due to its hybrid nature. > But due to it's PE nature during the early booting stages, it will without doubt have the same ability to run on 'all' hardware that every PE has. > >
> > ![:idea:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/idea.gif) What you *think* **knoppix** does might be VERY interesting :smile:, but it is not what he reported doing. He reported that he boots a PE where the Registry and Windows directory has been overwritten (offline) with an XP one: > 1-i install a clear xp on my laptop with no drivers and no any more programs. > 2-install winpe to usb flash disk (4gb) > 3-on the full clear xp , i run "regedit" and export registry and save it; eg:addreg.reg > 4-then edit this reg file and change all path (c:\\program files) to (x:\\programs) and > (c:\\windows) to (x:\\i386) and all (c:\\\*\*) to (x:\\\*\*) > and copy this file to usb (i386\\system32) > > 5- then edit "software" file where (i386\\system32\\config) > and add value to the (microsoft\\windows\\currentversion\\run) that "hiderun /w reg import addreg.reg) > > 6- **then copy** all files into the windows folder in the usb i386 folder (not only system32\\config folder) > > ***then*** boot from usb
jaclaz

forumNotes.content:

Where exactly do you see the difference?

forumNotes.author: MedEvil
forumNotes.content:
> He reported that he boots a PE where the Registry and Windows directory has been overwritten (offline) with an XP one: Sorry, overlooked this sentence. You are the one reading knoppix wrong. :tongue: :smile: knoppix only overwrites the directory offline. The registry is overwritten, when the run key is executed by explorer.
![:idea:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/idea.gif)

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
> Sorry, overlooked this sentence.  
> You are the one reading knoppix wrong. :tongue: :smile:  
>
> knoppix only overwrites the directory offline. The registry is overwritten, when the run key is executed by explorer.

***Maybe*** I see. :tongue:  

This:  
> 6- then copy all files into the windows folder in the usb i386 folder (not only system32\\config folder)
actually means:  
> 6- then copy all files into the windows folder in the usb i386 folder (***exclusion made for registry hives in*** system32\\config folder)

:tongue:  

So at each boot, he imports a "full registry" every time?  

And how are the changes saved?  

Or they are not?  

And each time he detects "New Hardware"?  

But then, where are the drivers to support "all" hardware?  

And if the "source" XP is "clean", and changes aren't saved, when/where are apps installed?   

Still, as I see it, it's a PE (sort of).  

![:idea:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/idea.gif)  

jaclaz

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
> but doesn't it limited to some specific brands ? all i can remember is , there is some lenovo tool which flips that bit . but it aint work universally or am i wrong ?

Maybe it's "Lexar", not Lenovo. ![:idea:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/idea.gif)  

[http://www.911cd.net...showtopic=21850](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=21850 "External link")  

And of course it is ***NOT*** universal, it only works on those stick that use the same controller the Lexar sticks use.  

It is a simplified version of the actual "Manufacturer Tool" or "Manufacturere Mass Production Tool".  

Latter ones are available for most makes/models of controller chips, but of course you cannot say "ALL" not "UNIVERSAL".  

Since you are reknown to go peeking on Chinese boards :tongue:, get ChipGenius:  
[http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=4661](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/?showtopic=4661 "External link")  
[http://www.mydigit.cn/chipgenius.htm](http://www.mydigit.cn/chipgenius.htm "External link")  

But of course the only thing that "flipping the bit" does is to have the stick look like a hard-disk.  

Another good source (Russian) is:  
[http://www.flashboot...php?name=iflash](http://www.flashboot.ru/index.php?name=iflash "External link")  
[http://www.flashboot....php?name=Files](http://www.flashboot.ru/index.php?name=Files "External link")  

:smile:  

jaclaz

it is not important the name (pe or whatever) ofcourse this is a sort of pe because boots like pe. but after boot, automatically a full registry key importing the system (addreg.reg) and when installed or removed program i manually export the registry to addreg.reg file. so i am manually updating it.
and i don't need any more plugin for installing programs i can istall what i want.

forumNotes.author: MedEvil
forumNotes.content:
> So at each boot, he imports a "full registry" every time? Yes. > And how are the changes saved? He didn't say, but since it's an USB drive, there is no reason to not save the whole registry to addreg.reg before exiting and since the hives are not touched, the load routine will work every time. > And each time he detects "New Hardware"? Yes, that's because of the use of setupldr and that the system behaves just like a PE until explorer loads. This is also what makes this build working on all hardware. > But then, where are the drivers to support "all" hardware? I think he meant, it works on all hardware, not that it supports all hardware. Same as for instance nativeEX_barebone. It works on all hardware, but is not even close to support all hardware. :tongue: > And if the "source" XP is "clean", and changes aren't saved, when/where are apps installed? In the running 'Full XPPE', i hope. Cause PE 'installed' software will loose some of it's registry entries. Namely those which also exist in the clean XP. :smile: > Still, as I see it, it's a PE (sort of). Sure it's sort of a PE, just as it is sort of a 'Full XP'. It's a hybrid system and thereby a cup half full, half empty thing. @knoppix Think i know where your network problem comes from. Network support is started after you merge the addreg.reg file into the registry and thereby make entries for services and maybe even the network card in the clean XP, which could collide with what PENetwork tries to do. You could try to run PENetwork before the registry merge. @jaclaz You seem to be pretty focused lately on correct english. Did you switch jobs and became an english teacher? :tongue:
![:idea:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/idea.gif)
edit: Ooops, cross posting.

@knoppix > i want to use full xp on usb flash disk. Please, note that (at least in a good communication) the naming is (very) important. Your PE environment, even if it does some things that other PEs do not (yet) do, is NOT a "Full XP": it remains a PE environment, with its advantages and its limits. So, if you want to really use a "Full XP" from your UFD then you can follow the suggestions that **jaclaz** has already pointed (or even you can perform a tutorial in my signature). Indeed, if you want "only" to enhance the *featuring* of your current PE environment, then please detail much more your network-issue: I'm sure that any member "PE-oriented" could help you. ![:idea:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/idea.gif)

forumNotes.author: MedEvil
forumNotes.content:
The used OS loader does **not** make the difference between a 'Full XP' and a PE. The registry setting SystemSetupInProgress does! It is quite possible to load a 'Full XP' with setupldr or a PE with ntldr. Though the adapting is usually a real pain in the behind! :tongue: What knoppix does: - augmenting a PE with all XP files --\> still a PE - towards the end of the boot cycle he overwrites the complete PE registry with a 'Full XP' one. --\> To all files startet after this point, the OS is a 'Full XP'. To all files started before this point it is still a PE. So the end result is a hybrid system, with one part reacting exactly like a PE, while the other reacts exactly like a 'Full XP'. I would guess that the behavior of the system as a whole is mostly unpredictable, due to its hybrid nature. But due to it's PE nature during the early booting stages, it will without doubt have the same ability to run on 'all' hardware that every PE has.
![:idea:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/idea.gif)

To all files started before this point it is still a PE. > > So the end result is a hybrid system, with one part reacting exactly like a PE, while the other reacts exactly like a 'Full XP'. > > I would guess that the behavior of the system as a whole is mostly unpredictable, due to its hybrid nature. > But due to it's PE nature during the early booting stages, it will without doubt have the same ability to run on 'all' hardware that every PE has. > >

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
> but doesn't it limited to some specific brands ? all i can remember is , there is some lenovo tool which flips that bit . but it aint work universally or am i wrong ?

Maybe it's "Lexar", not Lenovo. ![:idea:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/idea.gif)  

[http://www.911cd.net...showtopic=21850](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=21850 "External link")  

And of course it is ***NOT*** universal, it only works on those stick that use the same controller the Lexar sticks use.  

It is a simplified version of the actual "Manufacturer Tool" or "Manufacturere Mass Production Tool".  

Latter ones are available for most makes/models of controller chips, but of course you cannot say "ALL" not "UNIVERSAL".  

Since you are reknown to go peeking on Chinese boards :tongue:, get ChipGenius:  
[http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=4661](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/?showtopic=4661 "External link")  
[http://www.mydigit.cn/chipgenius.htm](http://www.mydigit.cn/chipgenius.htm "External link")  

But of course the only thing that "flipping the bit" does is to have the stick look like a hard-disk.  

Another good source (Russian) is:  
[http://www.flashboot...php?name=iflash](http://www.flashboot.ru/index.php?name=iflash "External link")  
[http://www.flashboot....php?name=Files](http://www.flashboot.ru/index.php?name=Files "External link")  

:smile:  

jaclaz

forumNotes.author: MedEvil
forumNotes.content:
> So at each boot, he imports a "full registry" every time? Yes. > And how are the changes saved? He didn't say, but since it's an USB drive, there is no reason to not save the whole registry to addreg.reg before exiting and since the hives are not touched, the load routine will work every time. > And each time he detects "New Hardware"? Yes, that's because of the use of setupldr and that the system behaves just like a PE until explorer loads. This is also what makes this build working on all hardware. > But then, where are the drivers to support "all" hardware? I think he meant, it works on all hardware, not that it supports all hardware. Same as for instance nativeEX_barebone. It works on all hardware, but is not even close to support all hardware. :tongue: > And if the "source" XP is "clean", and changes aren't saved, when/where are apps installed? In the running 'Full XPPE', i hope. Cause PE 'installed' software will loose some of it's registry entries. Namely those which also exist in the clean XP. :smile: > Still, as I see it, it's a PE (sort of). Sure it's sort of a PE, just as it is sort of a 'Full XP'. It's a hybrid system and thereby a cup half full, half empty thing. @knoppix Think i know where your network problem comes from. Network support is started after you merge the addreg.reg file into the registry and thereby make entries for services and maybe even the network card in the clean XP, which could collide with what PENetwork tries to do. You could try to run PENetwork before the registry merge. @jaclaz You seem to be pretty focused lately on correct english. Did you switch jobs and became an english teacher? :tongue:
![:idea:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/idea.gif)
edit: Ooops, cross posting.

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
> it is not important the name (pe or whatever) Hey, **knoppix** , can we move away from this ping-pong? The name is not important, the way it boots is. Had you answered plainly to my question the first time: [http://www.boot-land...?...c=8615\&st=3](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=8615&st=3 "External link") we would have already been ahead of where we are now. Us understanding what you do is vital in order to (hopefully) help you with the problem you are having. **Medevil** described quite clearly about the "hybrid" situation of your build. I find the idea of the "hybrid" build very, very interesting ![:idea:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/idea.gif), though it probably needs some refining. Now, what about posting some actual ***details*** on the build and on the problem you are having? At first look, the problem might be in your "integral" approach. If I get it right the addreg.reg is a HUGE file containing a whole Registry. :tongue: A quick test of exporting the whole Registry on my machine created a 58 Mb file. :smile: Out of curiosity, what is the booting time of you hybrid build? And when you install somethig you re-export the WHOLE Registry again or just the Software hive? When you install an app you do another "integral" saving of the Registry? It is possible that by copying over indiscriminately the Registry of a XP over a PE you overwrite or change some settings peculiar to the PE that prevents network from working. :tongue: Maybe it's time you have a look at the "common sense advice" attached to Rules: [http://www.boot-land...?act=boardrules](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?act=boardrules "External link") and start helping us in trying and helping you. Please forget for a moment about your "hybrid" build, and answer these questions: * Does the PE you build have network working (BEFORE importing the adreg.reg and copying the files to it)? * Does the "source" XP you use have network working?
A semi-random idea, what if you remove the "hiderun /w reg import addreg.reg" from tthe Registry and you try running it at a later stage, when the PE has completely booted? :tongue:
As a note, please avoid quoting entire posts, after you press the Quote button remove everything but the single sentence or concept you are replying/referring to, this way it is much easier to follow a thread, see how **Medevil** replied to my previous post, I shortened you Quotes to increase readability of the Topic.
@MedEvil Yes, but only for people that question ***my*** English or that post what IMHO appear as inaccurate info because of some easily correctable lack of familiarity with the subtleties of the language. :tongue: jaclaz

forumNotes.author: MedEvil
forumNotes.content:
@jaclaz  
To turn this idea into a fine working machine, the XP registry would need to be adapted to not overwrite any of the registry entries that deal with services and drivers.  
Probably the best solution would be a two stage approach.  
Stage 1: A controlled merge, while offline, of setupreg.hiv and the system.  
STage 2: After initial booting up, the whole rest gets merged in, to add entries and correct / overwrite unwanted PE settings.  

![:idea:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/idea.gif)

forumNotes.author: knoppix
forumNotes.content:
> Stage 1: A controlled merge, while offline, of setupreg.hiv and the system.

how can i do this???

forumNotes.author: sanbarrow
forumNotes.content:
do not overwrite entries such as:  

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\SYSTEM\\ControlSet001\\Services\\{22D8FAEA-C268-4B93-9192-CE41508E58CF}  
HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\SYSTEM\\ControlSet001\\Services\\Tcpip  
HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\SYSTEM\\ControlSet001\\Services\\Winsock  
HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\SYSTEM\\ControlSet001\\Services\\Winsock2  

this will very very likely result in non-functional network - it does matter if you do this after or before penetcfg ....

> HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\SYSTEM\\ControlSet001\\Services\\Winsock  
> HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\SYSTEM\\ControlSet001\\Services\\Winsock2  
>
> this will very very likely result in non-functional network - it does matter if you do this after or before penetcfg ....

forumNotes.author: MedEvil
forumNotes.content:
> how can i do this???
Eighter manually by knowing what you're doing or by someone writing a program or script to do it.   
> how can i make write protected these entries?
You can't!  
But you could delete those entries in the addreg.reg. Though this could fix the network problem, i doubt that this will be the end of your problems.  
The uncontrolled merge could potentialy create all kinds of strange issues.  

![:idea:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/idea.gif)

forumNotes.author: sanbarrow
forumNotes.content:
Maybe split your addreg.patch into many many small pieces and apply one by one.  

In most cases I tried to apply large system-registry patches after boot this failed - and doing so does not speeed up the process of finding out what you actually need.  
So do it in small steps one by one

Creating a number of small "sets" of Reg keys (and corresponding addreg***xy*** .reg's seems like the right approach, and of course re-combining them in a "monolithic" addreg.reg should be easy.
